designContent.title: Wireframes
designContent.explanation: I have designed wireframes for both laptop and phone screens. In the images below please note that the text in red is the Visual design element, the green is the Visual Response, and the blue is the Interaction points. These help breakdown the website and its various elements.

part1.title: Website Wireframes
part1.description: For the Home page, I have slightly varying layouts per section.  The homepage has a video on the top then it has “cards” which are links to blog pages. These blog pages are articles about sea life and how to conserve it. After that is the About Us section which is plain text and not in a bordered box. There is a section called “This is why we care” where pollution statistics are shown, this section has a border.
part1.description2: The images on this site have a grid layout (the pictures are next to each other) and when the screen is resized the images are one below each other.

part2.title: Phone Wireframes
part2.description: These wireframes show consideration of mobile-first designs. (Please Visit the Theory Section for research). Through my research, I found that only necessary information needs to be presented on mobile devices and this means cutting down on content and focusing on how the design needs to change to account for the smaller screen size.
part2.description2: An example of where this was considered is in the navbar. When the screen has a larger width the “Exploration” button is present, this button acts as a drop down menu for the “cards”, as spoken about above. When the screen size is smaller a drop-down menu makes interaction much more difficult as the text size would need to be smaller to account for the opening of a drop-down menu and a user is still able to access this through the home page “cards”.
part2.description3: Another example of mobile-first design is removing the intro paragraph on the video. This is removed on smaller devices as the video width changes and by removing it completely it reduces scroll time from if it were moved to below the video.

designContent.title: IXD Process
designContent.explanation: In this section we look at how the user is encouraged to interact and the process that they follow as they navigate the website.

part1.title: Goal Alignment
part1.description: The overall goal that this website has is to inform and to make learning fun so that the user gains an interest in caring for the ocean. As a designer I need to make this website accessible on different screen sizes because the target audience is not limited to a specific age group thus any user with any device can access this website. Anyone who is curious about the ocean has something to do on this website. The user's goal is to learn more information about the ocean and engage with the content in a meaningful way.

part2.title: Infrastructure
part2.description: The user has a goal which is to answer most of the questions on the quiz page correctly. The user starts off by needing to learn about sea life. The quiz is broken up into separate sections so the user can, for example, learn about sharks and then answer the questions on sharks. The user can navigate back to the pages and learn about a different animal then answer the corresponding questions. To account for this type of user, the quiz not only gives an indication of correct and incorrect attempts but also gives explanations. There is a results page after the quiz that shows the user which questions they correctly/incorrectly answered.

part3.title: Userflow
part3.description: The user starts on the home page, this page creates the need for the user to want to learn more. It shows pollution stats to educate the user on why caring for the ocean is important then it creates interest by showing the user interesting facts. The users are given options of cards to click these cards leading them to separate pages each one on a different sea life. After learning about a specific animal, the user can click the quiz on the nav bar and they can choose which quiz to answer for their chosen sea animal.
part3.description2: The navbar is at a fixed position and it indicates at all times to let the user know where they are. The user can easily navigate between pages without relying on memory.

part4.title: Interface Explanation
part4.description: The interface element is the navbar that allows the user to navigate through different pages and when the screen size is smaller it turns into a burger button. The other interface elements are the buttons on this website. The buttons are used to navigate back to pages, start quizzes, and generate new lists of facts.

part5.title: Style Process
part5.description: This website is inspired by the websiteOceanInfo.com and all of the referrence images below are from this website.
part5.description2: The aspects of the reference website that is used in this website are the use on icons on facts and the cards on the home pages. The articles are also laid out in a similar manner.

designContent.title: Style Guide
designContent.explanation: In this section, we will look at the goals of the website and visual designs. We will unpack fonts and color choices.

part1.title: Goal and Aesthetic
part1.description: Creates a sense of immersion and exploration, aligning with the interactive learning aspect

part2.title: Font Choices
part2.description: Poppins font is used for the majority of the content on this website and Dream Outland Pro is used for smaller headings for some sections
part2.description2: Poppins font was chosen since Sans-serif fonts like Poppins are generally considered easier to read on screens compared to serif fonts. It is also a well-balanced sans-serif font that works well for both headings and body text thus versatility was a factor in this choice.
part2.description3: Dreamland Pro is a display font, and these fonts are often chosen for headings because they can add a touch of personality and interest. Dreamland Pro's playful style might be intended to make the learning experience more engaging, especially for younger audiences.

part3.title: Implementation Notes
part3.description: In order to implement the process in the image below, I had to break up each box into its own script and then I had to break it down further. An example of this was that for the cards I called each Json data in its own script then I brought all those components into an InfoCard.jsx file. This makes work more manageable and readable for the next time I have to return to this code.

part4.title: Visual Design
part4.description: This website uses svgs waves  which correlates with the ocean theme while also  giving the website a more playful look. This wave theme is used frequently and is shown by the animated footer that looks like waves moving across the screen.Another aspect of this wave theme used in this website is in the responsive navbar. When the screen size is smaller how the background of the navbar opening emulates a wave that is swiping across the screen.
part4.description2: The colour palette chosen for this website is a lighter blue and white background which fits with the ocean theme and it works well with the images which are of sea life the have some blues in the background.
part4.description3: Light blue evokes shallows, dark blue represents depths, white provides clean background, and black adds contrast.

designContent.title: Feedback- Information Architecture
designContent.explanation: Information structure is one area that I needed to work on for this website and it has 3 elements

part1.title: Organization
part1.description: This refers to the logic of the structure of the website (Why are elements placed in certain positions? Is it a good design choice -Are the elements related? How will placement affect interaction?). This looks at how a designer can create a clear path for users to navigate the website.

part2.title: Structure
part2.description: This looks at how the content is laid out and how this guides the user.

part3.title: Labeling
part3.description: Refers to the buttons and titles on the page and how they influence the user interaction.

part4.title: What changed?
part4.description: Areas that I improved on concerning Information Architecture are mostly in the design section. It followed a similar layout to the rest of the website’s blogs; however, it contains more than twice the amount of content and it involves multiple areas of interest. This meant that it needed a different design, I decided to replace the layout which had all the blogs one after the other and replace them with cards similar to the home page. These cards had a heading for which section they direct the user to and a short description. When the user clicks on a card it alters the page to show them the specific “blog” that they have requested. To help the user know where to proceed there is a back button and a next button that the user is able to navigate through the blog list in the design section. This makes the information in the design section easier to digest as the user is presented with smaller chunks of information.
part4.description2: Reference: Hannah, J. (2023). What is information architecture? - UX Design Institute. [online] www.uxdesigninstitute.com. Available at: https://www.uxdesigninstitute.com/blog/what-is-information-architecture/.

designContent.title: Feedback- ‌User Interface Design
designContent.explanation: It is the point of contact between humans and computers. Design affect the look and feel of the website.

part1.description: This involves the clarity of communication with the user.

part2.description: An example is a button, although they come in many designs, simple style tells the user that it is something that can be interacted with. This is in the form of hover effects with changes in text weight, background colours and borders. Manipulating this element to show the user that this component on a website is a button and it gives them visual feedback and makes the website look more lively. The buttons previously on this website weren’t as easy identifiable like in the image below
part2.description2: Reference: Coursera. (n.d.). What Is UI Design? Definition, Tips, Best Practices. [online] Available at: https://www.coursera.org/articles/ui-design.
